text: this is a tiny little French mackerel
and I'm sure you've seen them they come
in all sorts of beautiful colors and
delicious flavors they probably seem
impossible to make at home but they're
actually quite easy there's only four
ingredients and I'm going to show you
how starts with skinless sliced almonds
71 grams they'll come out perfect every
time if I just weigh it into the food
processor with the almonds now I'm going
to grind this first and get it very fine
before I add the sugar okay that looks
pretty fun
now we weigh out this sugar and it's
confectioner's sugar it's about a cup or
117 grams in this goes and we're going
to grind them together this is the best
way to get the almonds superfine without
them becoming an almond butter I like to
pulse it a few times so that it doesn't
gather in the corner so I'm going to put
it through the sifter and make sure all
those lumps come out you have to do a
few times because you just want it as
fine as possible so I have some larger
pieces here I'm going to put this back
in the food processor for another
go-around
okay back into the sifter this really
creates the texture and taste of the
cookie it's all about these almonds with
the nice sweetness of the sugar and
we're ready to move on to the egg whites
I need two egg whites room temperature
very important you'll get the most
volume out of your eggs if you keep them
at room temperature save those egg yolks
for another use make a lemon curd
actually lemon curd is a great filling
for a mackerel
then granulated sugar and I'm going to
weigh again it's about a quarter of a
cup which is 53 grams this goes right
into the egg whites I like to just start
it with the whisk and then it's going on
to the mixer and the mixer is going to
do all the work so two minutes at speed
four to start us off and you can see the
sugar is nicely dissolved in the egg
whites so I'm going up to speed six for
another two now they're two minutes have
gone by we're getting some volume some
whiteness in the egg whites I'm going to
go up to speed eight for two more
minutes okay that's our final two
minutes now this is the point where you
add any kind of flavoring or any kind of
coloring to that macaron base I'm going
to make a rose raspberry macaron today
so I'm going to add a tiny bit quarter
teaspoon of rose water so perfumey and
lovely and then a few drops of a rose
pink color you can use as much color or
as little as you want
that was two drops let's see how pink we
get
mixture is done and this is exactly what
you want to see all this egg white in
the whist it's nice and thick like that
you know that you've got it know the
almonds go in and this is the fun part
everything goes in at once as you fold
this in we're actually going to be
deflating the egg whites somewhat will
become loose and flow like lava that's
what we're going for this is a folding
method that's very specific to macarons
pressing through that's one fold for
this we need 35 to 40 folds and it's
very specific you want to get it to the
point where it's still thick but flowing
so I'm going to start counting that was
1 2 3 4 33 34 35 now I check it it's
flowing thickly but still staying I'm
going to give it maybe two more folds 36
37 now that seems to be flowing better
now this goes into a pastry bag I have
one here in a glass and now the batter
goes in still very thick this is perfect
if it's too loose it's going to just fly
right out of the pastry bag and now it's
time to pipe I have a little bit of
batter left for my spatula I'm going to
just use this to dab under the parchment
paper to secure it to the sheet when I
have my batter lift up this collar I
like to keep the tip about a half inch
from the baking sheet when I pipe so I'm
really letting it fall down about a
three-quarter inch round and I twirl off
to the side
and of course these can be made much
bigger they can be made much smaller
they can be piped into hearts if you
want really this is where you could get
quite creative I have an oven preheating
to 350 degrees we have to wrap the
baking sheet against the counter this is
an important step to bring the air
bubbles up and out of the cookies so
don't be shy it's a loud bang about
three times and you can see the bubbles
come to the surface and that's all you
need now it goes into the oven these are
the baked mackerel they have cooled
they've come off the baking sheet so I
just run a spatula underneath make sure
they're all loosened now we're going to
build them and the filling can be
anything really as long as it's not too
loose I'm going to use a raspberry jam
but you could use a butter cream or a
ganache or a lemon curd the filling goes
on the underside the flat side of the
cookie I find piping it gives a nice
even amount of filling and I'm going to
leave it a little bit from the edge so
when you sandwich it will spread to the
edge jiggle it a little bit to get it
spread to the edge and that one's
perfect
once they're all filled these go into
the refrigerator you would never eat a
macaron like this it's very very crisp
and crunchy right now the final texture
that you want to get is a crisp outside
with kind of a chewy soft middle and
that will happen in the refrigerator the
amount of time it takes to soften it
really depends on the filling I like to
save 24 to 48 hours I'm just going to
keep filling
you
